question: A 21
sols_html:
We will row reduce until we arrive at an upper triangular matrix, taking care to keep track of changes to the determinant due to elementary row operations. First, let’s use the first row as a pivot

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle R2 \to R2-R1,\end{aligned}\]

\(\displaystyle R3 \to R3-3R1\), and \(\displaystyle R4 \to R4+2R1\). This doesn’t change the determinant, and we end up with

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 & 1\\ 0 & 1 & 2 & 0\\ 0 & -1 & -3 & -1\\ 0 & 6 & 9 & 3\\ \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

Now use the second row as a pivot

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle R3 \to R3+R2\end{aligned}\]

and \(\displaystyle R4 \to R4-6R2\). This doesn’t change the determinant, and we end up with

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 & 1\\ 0 & 1 & 2 & 0\\ 0 & 0 & -1 & -1\\ 0 & 0 & -3 & 3\\ \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

Now use the third row as a pivot

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle R4 \to R4-3R3.\end{aligned}\]

This doesn’t change the determinant, and we end up with

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 & 1\\ 0 & 1 & 2 & 0\\ 0 & 0 & -1 & -1\\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 6\\ \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

Since this matrix is upper triangular, the determinant is the product of the diagonal entries, \(\displaystyle -6\). The original matrix has the same determinant since we only added multiples of one row to another, which does not affect the determinant. Thus, \(\displaystyle \det B = -6\).
